The truth is, bigger IS better. Yes, it's definitely true that a sperm whale's brain is much bigger than ours, but their intelligence is lacking compared to hours; but that's only part of it. Sperm whales have large brains due in part to their large body size, and their brains have to keep up with maintaining that large body. What I believe to describe "brain power" is a proportional brain mass to body mass ratio. The bigger the brain is compared to the body, the smarter and more capable the organism can be.


We are humans, and our brains are massive compared to other species and ancestors, we have evolved to use our brains and intelligence for our survival, more rather than brute force and complete dominance in other species. Compared to our body however, the brain is still pretty small, although it is arguably the most important organ in the body, so I believe that the smaller it is, the less chances it has to get damaged. I looked this up just now, and the brain average brain is only 3 pounds, only 2 percent of our body weight. BUT, it takes up 25 percent of our intake of oxygen, 70 percent of the body's glucose, and 25 percent of the body's nutrients.

I believe a bigger brain is better, it possesses too many risks. Chances of head injuries may skyrocket, (due to a bigger head, duh). Our caloric and nutrient intake will boost by a lot, we're already pretty smart (for the most part) so it's just a waste and too risky of dying. Bigger brains are probably a turn off and may be seen as an abnormality, and even if someone greatly surpasses the IQ and brain power potential, I doubt it would solve many if any, of our problems, (spoiler for anyone who hasn't watched Lucy) as Lucy did when she reached "100%" of her brain potential. In the movie, she put all the world's problems' solutions onto a flash drive before she 'died', (this is from memory so don't quote me) and it was given to someone. IQ is only a person's capability to learn, so if someone with a high IQ didn't have the required resources, to a certain extent, that person can't even speak or do basic maths. This may be the same thing with a person who's really intelligent and has a massive brain and IQ to go along with it. If that person doesn't have the proper resources, he can't solve the world's problems efficiently, or even if he knew every single bit of information that other humans did, that person would only be capable of so much. Because we, as humans, don't know everything and are very flawed, and that very intelligent person will act upon those flawed ideals and information supplied by those flawed humans.

i think they got #6 wrong. The myth isnt entirely false. The reason you are right hand or left hand dominant is because of the opposite side of your brain is used slightly more (left hemisphere controls right side; right hemisphere controls left). It doesnt mean that there is a size difference or mental capacity difference. And language isnt only in your left hemisphere. Yes the temporal lobe (which controls hearing, comprehension of words, and language) is on the left side, but the temporal lobe isnt the only thing linked to language. Wernicke's area (located int he temporal lobe) comprehends the words and puts them in order in your brain, the message is then sent to the broca's area (in the frontal lobe) which controls speech muscles via the motor cortex. That message is sent to the Motor Cortex (parietal lobe) where the words will be pronounced.

This is so stupid that people are using the movie Lucy to argue against a claim that was  never made. Never did anyone make the point that 10% of our neural matter is functioning while the other 90% sits there dormant and unused. No movie or book has made that claim. The claim that we use 10% of our brain is pointing to the brains ability and capacity to function in different ways. That's the way the movies portray it and that it is ultimately what is meant by "10% of our brain". For example, when you play videogames your entire brain is functioning to different capacities in different parts of the brain. The whole brain is working. However, you are using a tiny piece of your brain's abilities. Let's say maybe even 10%? The whole brain is working but only at a small capacity. Read a book and you use the entire brain naturally to read and understand the thoughts being expressed in the boook. But a much different function than playing video games. Build a model airplane, learn how to dance, write a novel, draft plans to build a high rise building. Scientifically, no one ever said that there is a single piece of the brain matter being used to do those things while the rest of your brain does nothing but take up space in your head. But it could easily be only 10% of the brain's ability. As a matter of opinion, I believe that there is an entire world of things we can do with our brains that are virtually undiscovered. That doesn't mean that we don't use 100% of our brains. It means that we only use 10% of the functions that the brain has.

Just my 2 cents: From my understanding, number 1 is not a myth, not for primates at least. Primates, unlike most other organisms, have a unique trait where the neurons that compose the brain don't grow with the brain, but rather stay at about the same size.

This means bigger primate brains do, in fact, contain more neurons than smaller primate brains. It explains why we're the most intelligent species on the planet as opposed to other animals: we have the most neurons!

And there are studies being made that point towards cooking as being the main contributing factor to our sustainable brain size: other primates can't maintain a brain of our size because it uses more energy than they can supply their brains with through feeding continuously.

Cooking, on the other hand, basically predigests food in such a way that it is easier for our bodies to obtain the necessary nutrients from it, meaning we use less energy while eating and, thus, have more energy to spare and for our brain to use, although this has obviously backfired in recent years...

I believe here you are talking about the physical usage of the brain. It's true that 100% of the brain's MASS is being used, but surely not 100% of it's processing power.

I also think the "10% of it" is something else. For example, there are things we consciously control in our brain and other parts that we don't. For example, our heartbeat, the whole process of division of cells, fertilization--we don't consciously choose to do these things. We can hold our breath but we let it go (if we want to continue to live) and let our subconscious (or wtv) control it. I think the "10% of it" can also refer to our memories. Our brains remember a lot of things but we consciously (or not) have forgotten most of them to make space (maybe?) for new information (kind of like deleting files if I am getting this part right. These files are never gone per se--they are just in another form). But if we could control our brain consciously, we would control our heartbeats and every other thing we don't consciously control (and probably die in half a second). If we could control more, perhaps we could access all of the information since consciousness.

The myth about the brain is not that humans only use 10% of it. The myth is that we only use, on average, 10% of its total capacity or capabilities. To put that in perspective, if you are driving race car down the street at 15 miles per hour...you are using all the cars cylinders to propel the car forward but the car in fact has the potential to go 150 miles per hour. So that's not saying you are only using 10% of the engine etc. You are only using 10% of its speed potential/capacity.

This video is misleading for many reasons. Going in order:
1. Although simply comparing size is not an indicator of intelligence, the ratio of brain size to body size can be a decent predictor (although still has some exceptions). The encephalization quotient (the ratio of the expected brain size to the actual brain size based on body mass) is an even more accurate predictor. So size doesn't mean nothing (i.e. obviously a sperm whale is going to have a bigger brain, it's motor areas alone are probably bigger than the entire human brain).
2. Alcohol actually can and does actually cause death of some cells in the brain. Betz cells and purkinje cells are 2 that come to mind.
5. This one is correct, but I would like to add that you don't use more than 10% of your brain at the same time (like he said). You actually don't even use close to 10% of your brain at once. Doing so would likely result in an intense seizure. 
6. Although you don't necessarily use one side more than the other, there is such thing as right and left brained and it correlates with which side is stronger. Just as smarter people have more efficient and potentially more connectivity in their brain, one side of your brain is usually "smarter" than the other side. Although I don't remember exactly which functions are lateralized to which side of the brain, people do think differently based on which side of the brain is stronger or more dominant.
7. The five senses are simply a general categorization of all the different ways our body senses the surroundings. Yes pain is sensed from different types of nerves than simple touching and even stays segregated all the way up to the brain, but they can both be put into the "feel" category of sensing because they are in the same area of the brain (the somatosensory area). There are only 5 main sensing areas in the brain (feel, smell, taste, see and hear) and these can be subdivided.

The left and right brain dominance is an actual thing, but it doesn't mean you use that side of the brain "more". The jist of it is which side of your brain do you use for language. Most people are left brain dominant and a higher percentage of left handed people are right brain dominant although still a minority (remember right brain controls left side of body and vice versa).

So if you have a stroke that takes out your dominant side, you won't be able to speak. Your non-dominant side also does important things but it's a lot less noticeable than not being able to talk or comprehend language. They are a bit less localized than speech as well so hard to get rid of it all with a single stroke (unless it's large of course). Stuff like math, spatial orientation, music, etc are usually more non-dominant side traits but if you lose like 50% of your math function, you can function well enough in society. Lose 50% of your word comprehension and you'd barely be able to communicate.

@AsapSCIENCE Just an fyi, according to Michio Kaku's book The Future of the Mind, the left side of your brain always makes the final decision on what your body does, says, what you want to be when you grow up, etc. It's been observed that each side of the brain actually has it's own consciousness, but the only one we are aware of is the left. People with severe epileptic seizures have the corpus callosum cut, because that connection from the left side of the brain to the right side of the brain is causing feedback. When this is cut, the right side of the brain (which controls the left side of your body) is no longer under the dictatorship of the left. There have been documented cases of the right, mute, side of the brain having a much different agenda than your left. One being when a man was about to hug is wife, only to find that his other arm had a completely different agenda. It delivered a right hook to her face. When this was being noticed, tests to see if the right brain had it's own conscious were under way. Since the right brain can't control speech, but can understand and read it, the tests were made so that it could respond to questions using scrabble letters. They would cover the right eye (which is how the right brain sees) and ask the left brain a question (one question being if the person was a believer). Of course it responded using speech, the left said it was an atheist. When they covered the left eye so that the right brain could see, and asked it the same exact question, that's when it got interesting. Using the scrabble letters, it spelled out that it was a believer.

What does it even mean to be 'using' 10% of your brain? Your not consciously operating your brain, so your actually not using anything. All of your brain is CONSTANTLY working though it may work some areas more than others. You can imagine all the parts of the brain as the muscles in the rest of your body. When you run, your using all of your muscles, but your legs and your glutes are just pushing harder...

Physical pain is not a felt without touch, so it can't be considered a sense by itself. Mental pain cannot be considered a sense, because that pain is coming from inside you. It can be caused externally, however that pain still lies dormant in you, not from the outside world. Senses detect stuff coming from the outside world so concepts of physical pain and balance come from touch because you feel it with your body. Yes you have 5 senses, anything else you feel happens because you felt it from them. And no there is no 6th sense, that's all in your brain.

It's not absolute brain size but relative brain size.  The bigger the animal, the bigger the brain needs to be just to control all the bits.  Extra brain mass on top of that is more or less devoted to different kinds of intelligence.  So size does matter - you just need to consider body size as well.

We cannot sense temperature.  We sense heat loss and heat gain, which is at best a rough proxy for temperature.  That's why metal feels colder than wood - same temperature, different rate of heat transfer.  And why we have wind chill numbers - we lose heat faster via convection with wind, so it feels colder than a still air of the same temperature.

I would say one of the biggest myths about the brain is that there is empirical evidence connecting consciousness to the brain. In fact, philosophically, the mind body problem is more logically solved by dualism. Many philosophers and scientists are dualists because of the logical problems with a purely materialistic standpoint.

I think misunderstanding the dualism standpoint stems from the fact that most people don't fully understand the mind-body problem, and don't understand brain physics as well.

First, the brain operates like a machine, Information stimulates neurons from nerve connections, this electrical stimulation is is 'measured' by the neuron, and because of it's programmed tolerance, it may or may not pass on the stimulation to the next neuron in the network. The information propagates through the network, and back out through nerve connections to move limbs, speak, etc.  Stimulation flowing through your brain will cause your neurons to adjust their tolerances to better respond to stimulation next time, this is learning.

In short, a brain is a mechanical system that is set up to respond to certain stimulus in a way that is favorable to a certain situation. Here's the problem, the mind problem. As any conscious being is aware, we are aware. The great 'I', you can have conscious experience. Information ceases to be a physical propensity to respond to a situation favorable, and it becomes a feeling.  I don't pretend to know exactly how this phenomenon occurs, but I can tell you that due to the architecture of the brain, something is missing. Some say that information 'links-up' in the brain and you get an experience, or a certain amount of processing 'creates' an experience. When you think about it, all processing and linking could do is grant your brain better reaction to stimulus. Frankly, the brain is not built for consciousness and I doubt any mechanical system can be. Where do thoughts exist, and what makes red red? And where do all these things exist? I thought the brain stored information in a bunch of disjointed tolerances and propensities? 

How can we rectify our current knowledge of the brain with a necessary dualist perspective? I've heard materialists raise the argument of how brain trauma can effect consciousness and percept. This is an easily explained phenomenon, many dualists believe in a 'stream of consciousness', or a channel where processed brain information travels through to the metaphysical mind to become experiences. If you, for example, get your head bashed, your brain goes into trauma and cannot process information, thus your brain has no information to become experiences, thus no experiences. Another popular argument is that things like memory, image processing, etc can be traced to brain activity, these are called the soft problems of consciousness, this deals with the processing of incoming information, not the experiencing.

The reason some scientists are materialists and ignore the hard problems of consciousness, is because science is not suited to tackle the problem. Science is built on outside observation and definite values, not inside viewpoints and subjective experience. Another problem is that you can design a mechanical system with the propensity to respond to stimuli like a conscious being. You could make a robot behave like it has emotions, experiences, etc when it really doesn't have any.

A good analogy would be a lego brick representing intelligence and the ability to respond favorably to a situation. You can take millions upon millions of rectangular lego bricks and build a 'sphere' out of them. The more and more lego bricks you add, the more and more it will appear to be spherical, however, you can never build a true sphere out of lego bricks. Imagine taking a large amount of pliable clay and molding that around the sphere, with the added pliability of the clay, you can turn a pseudo-sphere into a true sphere. The brain 'built out of lego bricks' requires a pliable 'clay' to create a sphere (ie consciousness).

Scientists tackle things from the outside, consciousness can only be tackled from the inside.

So what is consciousness? It's order out of chaos. From the Soliton Model in Neuroscience to Ramsey Theory perhaps. If we can identify the biophysical mechanisms responsible for conscious thought we can reduce them into a combinatorial problem of which we can at the very least classify into a computational complexity class by a lower bound. This would be considered the first order quantification of consciousness. Assuming this complexity class is in NP-Complete then the P vs NP problem's solution will determine the fate of AI as to whether or not consciousness can be simulated on silicon computers.

Hold up, one second. The first "myth" you said is half wrong. It's true that the brain of a sperm whale is larger, and that sperm whales have a lower IQ than humans, but brain size does matter; it's just not the only thing that matters. To be precise, studies have shown that the brain to body mass ratio plays a big role in determining intelligence. While, given, it's not the only thing that matters (if it was, ants would be smarter than humans), it's certainly important and, because brain mass is half of the equation brain mass divided by body mass, brain mass is therefore important.

WRONG! I cant believe Im gonna say this but some of this myths are actually TRUE!.
The one about the 10%, isn't that "we use only 10% of the brain" but that "we use only 10% of the brain's potential". It means that yes: we use all parts of the brain but not all neuronal pathways! if we stop using a neuronal pathway it shrinks and gets weak. Studies have found that there are a lot of weak pathways and if a human could use more of the pathways at once it would significantly increase his cognitive skills.
Also, the one about "Bigger is better" you are comparing human brain to animal's brain! Between humans, developing a bigger brain means there's additional brain tissue which is correlated with a higher capacity to perform mental tasks :/
Lastly, a neuroscientist cousin told me you are correct on "Right Brain/Left Brain" because for example the amygdala(plays role on emotions/decisions/memory) has part on the right and left part of the brain. However, some skills are true to be on different sides. Language is on the left-brain and attention on the right-brain. If a person uses language more often, most of the neuronal pathways in that part of the brain are going to be stronger than other regions, and for that person using language is going to be easier than using math for example. When using language, yes, that person is going to use both parts, however is going to start on the left-brain's region related to language, which is also going to be more stronger.

I've seen before that there are more than the traditional five senses, but I still don't quite understand why the cited extra senses can really be considered separate senses. For example, separating temperature and pain from touch seems the same as trying to separate color from vision, or pitch from hearing, which we don't do. As for things like balance, how is it a sense at all? We can't "sense" anything but ourselves with these sorts of senses - if I'm trying to observe, say, a rock, I can do so with the traditional five senses, but I cannot use my sense of balance to tell anything about the rock. Categorizing the traditional five senses as a separate group from these weird internal "senses" seems much more useful and reasonable than lumping them all in together.

That 10% use is highly misinterpreted, you always use 100% of your brain, like when you drive a car slowly the whole car works, but you don't always use your brains full capabilities, like you don't always drive a car as fast as it can go. For instance, if you went down a busy street you won't actually remember all of the faces you saw, but your brain will notice them all and since they are of no value to you won't remember them. From your conscious standpoint your brain chose to remember just 10% of things that were important and not everything you were aware of at the time. Or you know that feeling if that's ever happened to you when something in your head says stop, you stop and something happens in front of you that could have hurt you, like a car going fast, or tree falling or such. Maybe that's your guardian angel and maybe that's your brain noticing stuff you aren't actually concentrating on. Or why savant people have extraordinary abilities after a brain damage of some sort, well because their brain just went wild and let them have instant memories or unlimited creativity or unlimited calculation resources or something like that.
